comments:
I get the attached exception fairly frequently.  The way that I end up solving
it is that I have a file called log4j.properties and it is modified.  So I take
that file copy it out and then in eclipse replace with latest, copy the old copy
back over top, and then do a refresh and do an update again and cvs update
works.  I have had this happen a few times.  I'll try and remember to just do an
update on that folder next time and then do a cvs update to ensure it isn't just
the update that is fixing it.

It is odd that the server would report an error without additional 
information. What CVS server version are you using. The next time it happens, 
could you follow the steps at the URL below in order to get a complete trace 
of the communications between the client and the server.

http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-vcm-
home/docs/online/cvs_features2.0/cvs-faq.html#misc_0

I'll turn that debug info on the next time I run across the error.  

We are using:

cvs version
  Concurrent Versions System (CVS) 1.11.6 (client/server)

So it looks like this problem occurs when I update and cvs finds a file with a
conflict so it inserts a little section like:

<<<<<<< log4j.properties

Now I keep that piece of text inside my file and run update again.  The cvs
server will then return an error and stop the updating of my source tree. 
Eclipse will also then fail to prune the empty directories.

I'll try and grab the debug info now.

This is the log from the dos console:

We are planning on addressing the markers created by an update in 3.0. we will 
look at this bug then.

I see the same cvs error without the exception on eclipse 3.0.1RC2, running on
Redhat 9 with IBM JDK 1.4.2-0.0.  If I try to update the directory from the
command line, there is a .cpp file that has a conflict.

After resolving the conflict, updating gives me an error message to refresh the
project.  After I refresh the project and update again, the update is successful.

I get this error in 3.2RC4 and it is rather annoying (yes, I do have conflicting changes in my workspace). There is no easy way to locate such conflicts as error message does not include any info about what resource has troubles updating.
You can easyly find the conflicts by performing a Team>Synchronize with Repository.
We no longer add the CVS markup on update so this issue should no longer occur.
As of which version will it no longer occur?
